item.title: Bessent, Kato Did Not Discuss FX Levels at G-7 Meeting, US Says
item.description: US Secretary Scott Bessent and Japanese Finance Minister Katsunobu Kato did not discuss foreign exchange levels during a meeting in Canada, according to a statement from the Treasury Department. The news sent the yen lower.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.

item.title: Stock Selloff to Hit Asia on US Deficit Concerns: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian equities were primed to fall Thursday after US stocks, government bonds and the dollar weakened on concerns about Washington’s ballooning deficit.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson

item.title: Duolingo AI Drives Top-Tier Subscriptions
item.description: Duolingo CFO Matt Skaruppa, who has positioned the world's most popular language-learning app for a new phase of growth powered by AI. Duolingo Inc. raised its full-year sales and profit outlook as artificial intelligence offerings drive users to its higher-priced subscriptions. Sales will be $987 million to $996 million this year, the company said in a letter to shareholders, up from its previous view of at most $978.5 million and ahead of analysts’ projections for $973.2 million. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Novogratz Reveals Why Galaxy’s Nasdaq Listing Took So Long | Bloomberg Open Interest 05/21/2025
item.description:
Get a jump start on the US trading day with Matt Miller, Katie Greifeld and Sonali Basak on "Bloomberg Open Interest." Fresh clues on the impact of Trump's tariffs as Target cuts its forecast, citing weak consumer spending. Meanwhile Lowe's bucks the tariff trend with a beat as earnings from Toll Brothers shows luxury demand holding up. On the political front, New York and New Jersey Republicans are said to capitulate, allowing Trump's SALT cap to be extended. And Billionaire Mike Novogratz discusses the challenging path to Galaxy Digital's Nasdaq listing.
Update: Removes banner which inadvertently attributes Ubide's personal views to Citadel (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Investing in Women's Sports With Mellody Hobson
item.description: Alex Rodriguez and Jason Kelly sit down with Mellody Hobson, co-CEO and president of Ariel Investments, to discuss her firm's newly launched fund, "Project Level," devoted to investing in women’s sports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Blue Owl Capital Targets Expansion to Retail Investors in Japan
item.description: New York-based alternative asset management firm Blue Owl Capital Inc. said it aims to enter the Japanese mutual fund market as early as next year.
item.dc:creator: Takako Taniguchi, Nao Sano

media:content.media:description: Buildings in the Shibuya district of Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 2, 2024. Fresh data on the Federal Reserve's various accounts hints at two potential ways Japanese policy makers may have funded currency interventions this past week to bolster the beleaguered yen. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: Earl Patton on the Business of Sports
item.description: Earl Patton, Managing Partner of Rumble Venture Capital speaks with Romaine Bostick and Scarlet Fu about investing in sports as an asset class. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Robinhood's Game Plan for Sports Prediction Markets
item.description: JB Mackenzie, Vice President and General Manager of Futures and International at Robinhood speaks with Romaine Bostick and Scarlet Fu about Robinhood's sports prediction markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fringe White Afrikaners See How Lobbying of Trump Can Work
item.description: The fringe group that planted the seed for some of Donald Trump’s unsubstantiated claims that South Africa is persecuting White farmers saw years of lobbying US politicians pay off.
item.dc:creator: Rene Vollgraaff

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump shows pictures as he meets with Cyril Ramaphosa in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 21.

item.title: 2025 Qatar Economic Forum Day Two Highlight
item.description: Highlights from day two of the 2025 Qatar Economic Forum, Powered by Bloomberg. International CEOs share unique perspectives on how the global economy is transforming in Doha, Qatar. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Bond Market Warns Trump, Congress on Dangers of Swelling Deficit
item.description: In the world’s biggest bond market, investors are pushing back against President Donald Trump’s tax-cut plan.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Liz Capo McCormick, Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: The White House and the US Treasury building in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, Feb. 24, 2025. Elon Musk’s demand that more than two million federal employees defend their work is facing pushback from other powerful figures in the Trump administration, in a sign that the billionaire’s brash approach to overhauling the government is creating division.

item.title: NYU’s Bond Rating Outlook Dinged Amid Large Capital Plans
item.description: The outlook on New York University’s credit rating was revised to negative from stable by S&P Global Ratings, which cited the school’s plans to ramp up debt for capital projects.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright

media:content.media:description: A New York University building in New York.

item.title: The Trump Family's Money-Making Machine
item.description: From crypto to licensing deals, Max Abelson and Annie Massa break down how President Trump has positioned his family to make more money while he’s in the White House. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stocks Get Hit as Weak Treasury Sale Boosts Yields: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street’s worries about a ballooning deficit that threatens America’s status as a safe haven were reflected in a $16 billion Treasury sale that saw lackluster demand - with stocks, bonds and the dollar falling.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth, Denitsa Tsekova, Emily Graffeo

item.title: 2025 Qatar Economic Forum Day Two Highlights
item.description: Highlights from day two of the 2025 Qatar Economic Forum, Powered by Bloomberg. International CEOs share unique perspectives on how the global economy is transforming in Doha, Qatar. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Activist Investor Who Won Pitney Bowes Proxy Battle Is About to Be CEO
item.description: The head of Hestia Capital Management is poised to become chief executive officer of Pitney Bowes Inc., about two years after the activist investor won board seats at the shipping services provider.
item.dc:creator: Liana Baker, Matthew Monks

media:content.media:description: The Pitney Bowes Las Vegas mega center.

item.title: Snowflake Reports Strong Outlook After the Bell | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Dollar Hits One-Month Low as G-7 Stirs Fresh FX Policy Watch
item.description: A gauge of the dollar touched its lowest mark in a month as traders awaited a Group-of-Seven meeting this week for any signs that the Trump administration is seeking a weaker US currency.
item.dc:creator: Vassilis Karamanis, David Finnerty

item.title: Market Tests Investors’ Nerves as Stocks Sell Off After Auction
item.description: Investors dumped US stocks Wednesday afternoon following a disappointing Treasury auction that sent bond yields surging past levels seen during April’s market rout.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Leon Cooperman Conservative on Stocks, Sees Rates Going Up
item.description: Omega Family Office Chair and CEO Leon Cooperman discusses the concerns he has about the current financial market environment and where he is finding investment opportunities on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Hinge Health, MNTN IPOs Test Strength of US Listing Rebound
item.description: The digital-health and advertising-technology sectors share a rich history of IPO disappointment, making this week’s planned debuts of physical therapy platform Hinge Health Inc. and TV ad software firm MNTN Inc. a test of whether the nascent recovery in the US first-time share sale market can keep going.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes, Natalia Kniazhevich

media:content.media:description: A Wall Street sign near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Monday, April 21, 2025. US stocks tumbled as President Donald Trump continued to verbally attack Jerome Powell, calling on the Federal Reserve chair to cut rates as signs mount the president's trade war is pushing the economy toward recession. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: CoreWeave Surges Past Analyst Targets as Citi Doubles Theirs
item.description: CoreWeave Inc.’s rally is running so hot it’s leaving analysts’ stock predictions in the dust. Citi Research more than doubled their 12-month price target on the stock to a Wall Street high Wednesday morning. When the market opened shares blew past it in the first 15 minutes of trading.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke

item.title: UnitedHealth Plunge Stunned Wall Street. One Analyst Saw It Coming
item.description: When CFRA’s Paige Meyer slapped a “sell” rating on UnitedHealth Group Inc. in February, she was the lone analyst out of 30 tracked by Bloomberg with a negative view of the company.
item.dc:creator: Angel Adegbesan

item.title: Canada’s Largest Pension Plan Quietly Abandons Net Zero Target
item.description: Canada Pension Plan Investment Board dropped its commitment to achieve net zero emissions by 2050 just three years after establishing the target.
item.dc:creator: Layan Odeh

item.title: Credit Score Stocks Slide as FHFA Head Questions Pricing
item.description: Fair Isaac Corp.’s shares saw their worst day since March 2020 on Wednesday, falling alongside credit bureau stocks after the head of the Federal Housing Finance Agency questioned credit report pricing.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Griffin

media:content.media:description: The Fair Isaac Corp. (FICO) logo displayed on a smartphone screen, on April 23, 2025.

item.title: UnitedHealth Group Downgraded to Sell at CFRA
item.description: CFRA analyst Paige Meyer downgraded UnitedHealth Group Inc. to "sell" in February, predicting a 22% fall in shares, which has since plunged 36% and lost $170 billion in market value. It's the latest in a string of negative moves for the stock. Denitsa Tsekova reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Greece Is (Not) the Word in Japan
item.description: The situation in Tokyo bears no similarity to the euro-zone crisis era in Athens. The comparison drawn by Shigeru Ishiba is reckless and irresponsible.
item.dc:creator: Gearoid Reidy

item.title: Why Ted Leonsis Is Bullish on Women's Sports
item.description: Monumental Sports & Entertainment CEO, Ted Leonsis, sat down with Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua during the Qatar Economic Forum to talk about his potential sports investments. Leonsis praised women's sports, particularly the WNBA. "The quality of the game in the way the game is being presented looks like the NBA," he told Lacqua as he recommended that investors should buy a professional women's soccer or basketball team. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Slips as US Stockpile Gain Overshadows Iran Strike Report
item.description: Oil dropped after a second consecutive weekly gain in US crude inventories overshadowed a CNN report that Israel is preparing for a potential strike on Iranian nuclear sites.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Charleston

media:content.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Bushehr province, Iran. Source: NurPhoto/NurPhoto

item.title: Future of AI Demand, as Nvidia CEO Slams US Chip Policy
item.description: Bloomberg Intelligence’s Mandeep Singh says the overall AI market will grow, but a shift is taking place from training to inference. Singh joins Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)
